Metadata: SOURCE:  UIS estimates: GALP CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: 2017 Socioeconomic Survey:_x000D__x000D_ The question ""Can you read and write?"" was performed on the population of 15 years or older. The interviewees chose among the alternatives: ""yes, read and write"", ""no, only read"", ""no, only write"" or ""no, no"". In national statistics, those who chose the first alternative described are considered literate. QUALIFIER: This data point is an ESTIMATE produced by the UNESCO INSTITUTE FOR STATISTICS.

Metadata: SOURCE:  UIS estimates: GALP CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: 2008 survey:_x000D__x000D_ (1) Survey processes and methods:_x000D__x000D_ Conducting a literacy test in the form of a structured questionnaire aimed at all individuals within the sample households carried out door-to-door._x000D__x000D_ (2) Survey questions:_x000D__x000D_  Basic 1) Participant is shown some Korean words and then asked whether he or she can read the words without any difficulty._x000D__x000D_   1. Can read without any difficulty  _x000D__x000D_   2. Have some difficulty but can read without assistance_x000D__x000D_   3. Cannot read without assistance_x000D__x000D_   4. Wrote name and address without any difficulty_x000D__x000D_  2. Had some difficulty but wrote name and address without assistance_x000D__x000D_  3. Wrote name and address with some assistance_x000D__x000D_  4. Cannot write because of a disability_x000D__x000D_ 'Literate people' includes both those who can read without any difficulty AND also people who can read and write despite some difficulties. Metadata: SOURCE:  UIS estimates: GALP CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: 2002 national census: _x000D__x000D_ Each person having completed more than three grades of primary school shall be considered literate. In addition, literate will be considered a person without school qualification and with 1-3 grades of primary school if he or she can read and write a composition (text) in relation to everyday life (i.e. read and write a letter regardless of the language and alphabet). However, if the person without education or with completed 1-3 grades of primary school cannot read and write a composition (text) about everyday life, i.e. read and write a letter, he or she will be considered illiterate. QUALIFIER: This data point is an ESTIMATE produced by the UNESCO INSTITUTE FOR STATISTICS.

Metadata: SOURCE:  UIS estimates: GALP CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: 2002 national census: _x000D__x000D_ Each person having completed more than three grades of primary school shall be considered literate. In addition, literate will be considered a person without school qualification and with 1-3 grades of primary school if he or she can read and write a composition (text) in relation to everyday life (i.e. read and write a letter regardless of the language and alphabet). However, if the person without education or with completed 1-3 grades of primary school cannot read and write a composition (text) about everyday life, i.e. read and write a letter, he or she will be considered illiterate. QUALIFIER: This data point is an ESTIMATE produced by the UNESCO INSTITUTE FOR STATISTICS.

Indicator Name: Literacy rate, population 25-64 years, female (%)
Metadata: CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: The indicator derived from questions that require respondents to indicate whether they have 'no difficulty', 'some difficulty', 'a lot of difficulty' or are 'unable to' ""Write a letter in at least one language"" and to ""Read (e.g. newspapers, magazines, religious books) in at least one language"". If individuals experienced 'a lot of difficulty' or 'were unable to do' either, they were considered 'illiterate'.  The questions were only asked of individuals aged 5 years and older who have not completed at least grade 7 as it was assumed that individuals that have completed primary school would be literate (particularly since we are using self-assessed questions). SOURCE:  General Household Survey

Indicator Name: Literacy rate, population 25-64 years, female (%)
Metadata: CHANGE (Data reporting): Literacy definition: Literacy is the ability to read and write with understanding in any language. (If an individual has 'A lot of difficulty' (3) or 'Unable to' (4) read (e.g. newspaper magazines, religious books) or writing a letter in at least one language, then the person is illiterate. Does ...... have difficulty in doing any of the following..._x000D__x000D_ a = Writing a letter in at least one language_x000D__x000D_ b = Reading (e.g. newspapers, magazines, religious books) in at least one language _x000D__x000D_ 1 = No difficulty_x000D__x000D_ 2 = Some difficulty_x000D__x000D_ 3 = A lot of difficulty_x000D__x000D_ 4 = Unable to do_x000D__x000D_ 5 = Do not know SOURCE:  General Household Survey

The questions were only asked of individuals aged 5 years and older who have not completed at least grade 7 as it was assumed that individuals that have completed primary school would be literate (particularly since we are using self-assessed questions).
